data.text: Marathon Plus Tire Coming off the Rim

Hi there, This Marathon Plus tyre 700 x 28C, sidewall pressures 80-110 psi, has given me good service over a few years and still has tread. This bike is quite new and only has a few hundred miles in. Just noticed the other day that at 100 psi one part of the tyre, the wire bead, is almost coming off the rim. I took all the air out and it all appeared to be seated ok but on pumping up again the same thing happened. No issue on the other side. Don‚Äôt think I should be cycling when it‚Äôs like this. Any ideas please?
How many kms?
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: sorry, not sure, as never used to record anything until quite recently. In the low thousands at a guess as it‚Äôs mostly a commuter for ten miles each way and leisure rides in between. Might be quite low actually as this rear tyre is my newest.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: I guess I should really take the wheel off and remove the tyre and tube, inspect, and start again, right? Just a pain with the M+üòÖ The beauty is, punctures are extremely rare. Think it only happened once and I‚Äôve used them in all my bikes for years.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: let the air out brake the seal and slide tyre to another spot on the rim .inflate again. If the tyre doesnt bead in the rim check the rim
data.author: Raymond Chatt

data.text: ok thank you. Will try this tomorrow üëç
data.author: Jon France

data.text: also you do not need to put 100psi in Marathons check the tyre If I remember right I think 85 in a 32 is max??
data.author: Raymond Chatt

data.text: 28C, 80-110 psi
data.author: Jon France

data.text: I will do that, cheers
data.author: Jon France

data.text: Trash.
data.author: Marc Pujol

data.text: nonsense..you simply reseat the tire.
data.author: Mitchell Paul

data.text: yeah, so probably just not seated correctly at fitting?
data.author: Jon France

data.text: no way
data.author: Jon France

data.text: try try again
data.author: Mitchell Paul

data.text: Use a little dishwashing soap on the beads and seat it again
data.author: Maurits Veenhuis

data.text: ok cheers for the tip. Will try this.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: Your tube needs to be taken out and placed again...it seems it may have moved and overlapped inside causing this...either that or the wire bead on the tire has broken
data.author: George Homer

data.text: thanks. Going to do this tomorrow.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: also when filling the tube with air only put a little...go around the wheel and recheck the bead...fill it slowly a little bit at a time (only a few pumps at a time) continuously checking the bead until it begins to get hard...once hard fill it up all the way
data.author: George Homer

data.text: thank you
data.author: Jon France

data.text: any time :)
data.author: George Homer

data.text: Interesting about the wire bead, thanks. Never had a problem fitting these tyres myself but this bike was put together by lbs including swapping out the tyres
data.author: Jon France

data.text: How wide is that tire? 100 psi is awfully high! Not that that's necessarily the problem but I don't run my road bike tires (25mm) any more that 80 psi. Nevertheless, if the bead is seated in the rim, then it looks like that wire is separating from the rest of the tire's carcass.
data.author: Adam Tripp

data.text: 28C. Says up to 110 psi on the side wall but open to advice
data.author: Jon France

data.text: Those sidewall max pressures are usually half the pressure it takes to blow the tire off the rim and are there more for legal purposes than anything else. People think higher pressures are faster but that‚Äôs not true: you actually have more rolling resistance because the tire doesn‚Äôt absorb as much of the vibrations from the road. For 28‚Äôs, I would probably run them between 60-70, but I would also experiment running them in the 50 psi range and see how that feels. It should make your ride much more comfortable, too.
data.author: Adam Tripp

data.text: ok, well I am here to be educated, so thanks for that. I will try some experimenting then, once I‚Äôve solved this issue. By the way, once I noticed this problem I let a ton of air out and ride ten miles home no problem at all. Think it was down to under 50 by then.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: Rated 55-85 psi you‚Äôre way over the top end I run at 65-70 same tire no issues.
data.author: Bobby Olsen

data.text: I have 700x35 maybe a narrower tire has a higher range?
data.author: Bobby Olsen

data.text: yes it‚Äôs 28C up to 110 psi. I will use 34C or similar when I replace, but economised by putting old tyres on new bike which came with crappy tyres.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: What the psi rating of the tyre , I normally don't go above 65psi , other damage the tyre or rim or both
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: 28C up to 110 psi. Old tyres on new bike. Will go wider on replacement.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: This is why I got the regular Marathons and not the Plus. A number of similar complaints by reviewers of the Plus.

data.text: they‚Äôve served me well since 2009 on several bikes and only punctured once in that time, so happy to keep using them. Have always fitted myself but lbs fitted these to a new bike and maybe something went wrong there?
data.author: Jon France

data.text: , most people here are pretty pro themselves, but this is why I have my mechanic install, so I know they are proper and worry-free.
data.author: Martha Doran

data.text: That‚Äôs high psi . Riding at high psi isn‚Äôt really a think now and not necessary
data.author: Sue Smoze

data.text: well it‚Äôs rated 80-110. So you‚Äôd ride at 80?
data.author: Jon France

data.text: I ride less and less again if tubeless .
data.author: Sue Smoze

data.text: I have had problem with double wall Aluminium 26 ' mountain bike rims popping , and tyre busting above 65 psi . I know racing bike narrow wheels can go higher . Yes is easier to ride the hard the tyre is hard , but the rim and the tyre both have to be rate for high psi
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: I get that with tubeless but do you ride way below the minimum rating on tubes? Not forgetting these are 28C and possibly thinner than your tyres.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: I will check the rim but this is a Cannondale Quick 1 flat bar road bike so shouldn‚Äôt be any issues there. It‚Äôs my workhorse commuter, leisure and light tour machine.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: I have a road bike with tubes and 28s and I use 70 psi but I‚Äôm not very heavy so yes ride at the bottom end at 80 and give that a go
data.author: Sue Smoze

data.text: Maybe the tyre bead is damaged and therefore cannot withstand the force being applied at that point, test this theory by marking the tyre at the point it is doing this. Deflate it and slide it around the rim maybe quarter way round. Inflate and see if this occurs at same point on tyre, if so throw it away. If it occurs at the same point on the rim and not the tyre then it is the rim, throw the wheel away üòÉ I wouldn't ride with that as it could pop off the rim at any time.
data.author: Mike Quinn

data.text: thank you for your advice. If it happens again I‚Äôd like to think it‚Äôs the old tyre I need to replace as this bike is only a few months old and has only been used on good roads and not high mileage.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: and yes, that is my fear too üòÖ
data.author: Jon France

data.text: Thanks everyone for all your replies. I‚Äôm sticking with Marathon Plus, as over many years and bikes I‚Äôve only ever had one flat so they are super reliable and speed is not my purpose. This tyre is 28C and rated 80-110 psi. Maybe I will try a bit lower than 100 next time. I will swap out for the next width up 34C? when I replace. Trust this to happen the only time I‚Äôve ever trusted a lbs to fit my tyres. Some great tips which I will be referring to tomorrow as my skills are pretty basic.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: I run 28 on my road bike. 100 is ok but not recommended. Basically you go 110 on 23, 100 on 25, 80-90 on 28. 80 on 32. my gravel bike tires and wheels are 60 psi max at 42. I just lazy and dislike to pump up wheels often otherwise would always go 10-15 bellow the limit.
data.author: Sergei Med

data.text: Any chance you got some of the rim tape shoved to the side making it difficult for the bead to seat?
data.author: Wacky Gochoco

data.text: ok another thing to check, thank you
data.author: Jon France

data.text: agree, rim looks deformed here
data.author: Gervase Barnes

data.text: I had similar problem, tyre rode slightly unevenly, and while stopped at drink stop, tube punctured due to being nipped under bead. Marathon Plus are quite hard to fit. I‚Äôve had more nipped tubes than punctures - I reckon I get about one puncture in a few thousand km, mostly from clearly identifiable nails or pins, and the tyres last longer than the chain. If I was going to change my MarathonPlus tyres, it would be for another Marathon Plus
data.author: Jonathan Bouchard

data.text: there‚Äôs a YouTube video with an old boy showing the trick to fitting these tyres. It‚Äôs easy when you know how.
data.author: Gareth Griffith

data.text: Is the rim flat-spotted? I'm looking at the photo from side-on and the tyre seems round but the rim seems to be flattened there.
data.author: Eugene Kolaric

data.text: that‚Äôs the bead of the tyre coming off the rim at that spot. Doesn‚Äôt happen at lower pressures.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: Just a word of warning , don't just trust filling pressure gauges , some of them are faulty and over inflate you tyres
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: On ours they typically come slightly deformed, pump to about 15 psi then move the bead with your hand to ensure it is properly seated. Then go to full pressure. After a few rides it should be in shape again and shouldn't give trouble in the future. As far as pressure, stick to the tires rating in general use. It is common to overinflate them to set the bead though, overinflation doesn't blow the bead off unless it wasn't on correctly in the first place.
data.author: Thomas Elliott

data.text: thank you. I never inflate past 100 and it‚Äôs rated to 110 but thanks for the info which makes sense. Just didn‚Äôt think it would get deformed.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: They commonly come deformed from the shipping process, but they pop back into shape with a little finger work.
data.author: Thomas Elliott

data.text: thanks buddy
data.author: Jon France

data.text: It‚Äôs no big deal. Just use the markings on the sidewall to align the tire with the rim with the tire about 20 psi then inflate fully
data.author: Tom Heutte

data.text: I've been on the Marathon Plus since 2011. Didn't change them until 2016. Now I have them on 2 other bikes. I also had the Marathon Plus GT Tour fitted on a fourth bike. Now, those are really, really good.
data.author: Steven  Ng

data.text: thanks. Will look into them next time I need new tyres.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: Well 100 psi is rather a lot for a touring tyre. Try 75 and see if it's OK

data.text: but the sidewall says 80-110‚Ä¶and mostly it‚Äôs commuting at the moment

I definitely will try riding at lower pressures but I will also inspect this tyre and wheel as suggested. Thanks for commenting.

data.text: rim could easily be replaced by any decent wheel builder. Just spin it in the frame and check as the rim goes past a stationary point

data.text: will do, thank you
data.author: Jon France

data.text: This usually happens when the tyre isn't seated properly, or you've pinched the inner tube, the valve stem isn't pushed in when inflating, again pinching the tube, over inflation, dodgy tyre, too much leverage thus damaging the tyre when fitting.
data.author: Karl Nickolls

data.text: thank you. My local bike shop fitted the tyres along with a heap of other stuff as it was a brand new bike. I‚Äôd like to think they weren‚Äôt too hasty with the tyres but you never know. Going to take it all apart tomorrow. Thanks.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: I‚Äôve had tubes nipped by the bike shop with Marathon Plus tyres - I can‚Äôt remember why I was asking the shop to fit the tyre, maybe I had a puncture and the bike was due a service in any case. I‚Äôd not recommend that shop on the basis of other experience of poor workmanship, but they are open on a Sunday and till 8 pm during the week; needs must, when the devil drives‚Ä¶
data.author: Jonathan Bouchard

data.text: To be fair, maybe I‚Äôd had enough of wasting tubes fitting the tyre myself, and I thought ‚Äúit‚Äôs overdue for a service anyway‚Äù. I find Marathon Plus hard to fit, and I waste more tubes fitting the tyre than with punctures on the road. But they really are puncture-resistant to the verge of bullet-proof.
data.author: Jonathan Bouchard

data.text: I agree, they are hard work to fit but worth the hassle
data.author: Jon France

data.text: the last puncture I had was a twisted nail that looked Like it had been deliberately twisted to lie point upward. I am not going to ask any tyre time survive that. My buddy rides Schwalbe Durano, and they are pretty good on puncture resistance as well.
data.author: Jonathan Bouchard

data.text: I think the 100psi is the max before it might blow. Not an advised riding pressure. Just pump it up enough so the rim doesn‚Äôt hit the ground on bumps. 40-50 is plenty
data.author: Dan Noble

data.text: well it‚Äôs 28C and the sidewall says 80 to 110 so your figures seem way off? Not having a dig. Just not understanding your drift.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: every tire has a rated working pressure on it. That's what the 110 max is on their tire. They work best when in that range for a number of reasons. You can go a little over or under, but they are designed for best use in that range. For instance, if I had my 1.0 x 26 at 40-50psi, as you suggest, I would be riding with my rims on the ground. At 100(as rated) it rides perfectly and very comfortable.
data.author: Steve King

data.text: this happens often when doin tires on motorcycles. you gotta massageÔøº it back into placeÔøº

data.text: It does actually state on the Tyre 55-75 bar, 80-110 psi which is visible in the picture if you look closely, so if you like to ride at 100 psi that's fine, it could just be the tyres age and the internal bead has stretched as it is steel wire just like a brake cable
data.author: Jon Woody

data.text: yeah that‚Äôs why I pumped up to 100. It‚Äôs others here who didn‚Äôt know, but I didn‚Äôt initially say the size or rating of the tyre, so my bad. Could well be that. Hoping tomorrow I will find out, thanks.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: About 1,500 miles into a cross-country ride of 3,800 miles‚Äîafter a lot of rough roads‚Äîthe bead on my rear 38c Marathon Plus broke. It was the only piece of equipment that broke on the entire trip. (Didn‚Äôt just stretch or deform, actually broke.) Had to flag down a guy with a pickup truck to get me to a bike shop to replace it. Bike-shop mechanic said he‚Äôd seen it before. Put another Plus on and had no problems for remaining 2,300 miles.
data.author: Richard Core

data.text: I kept PSI at about 80‚Äìrecommended level may be lower for 38c‚Äôs
data.author: Richard Core

data.text: 38c are rated to 85 psi, if I recall correctly
data.author: Jonathan Bouchard

data.text: Yep. 60-85 psi. The compact tire pump I was using didn't give me an exact readout, but I was generally in the 75-80 psi range most days.

data.text: If that fails at speed, its your safety. I would just replace it period and have peace of mind

data.text: food for thought, but will still take it off tomorrow and have a look, just to see what I can find. I‚Äôm not going to take any risks for the sake of ¬£30 or whatever.

data.text: Hi everyone Iam Waleed from Saudia Arabia planned to go with my friend bike touring in Europe planned to paddling on euro 15 from source to end First time in Europe hope I enjoy it Eny tips I will be thankful
data.author: Waleed A Khayyat

data.text: Swap the tyre to the other wheel. C if it ( the problem ) follows the tyre....
data.author: Pat Higgins

data.text: I have a relatively old Raleigh with hookless rims. These are tricky to get set right. I air them up partially and get the bead set uniformly around the rim. Air up halfway, check again. Adjust, then air up the rest of the way. I backed off on the top pressure about 10 psi.
data.author: William Albert

data.text: I had this experience a few weeks back where the tyre ended up getting strangely displaced like this on my girlfriend's bike and only realised when I put the new inner tube in and after I had inflated it to the "recommended" pressure. Shortly after that the inner tube exploded. With a new inner tube, and more careful positioning, the tyre is still fine. But this sounds a bit worse condition if uou can'tsolve it with the tyre, as the beading is almost outside the wheel. If you can't get it to stay reliably in, sooner or later (e.g go over a bit bump) I think you'd end up with a burst inner tube.
data.author: George Dibben

data.text: I agree. I won‚Äôt ride like that.

data.text: Try another tyre or inverse it to see if it‚Äôs the rim or the tyre change the faulty part. Tyre and wheel failure is best avoided.
data.author: Nigel Strang

data.text: Your comment Not hard to install.. tells me it is not a right fitting tire. 1. Baby powder the snot out of the inner tube and tire before you install again. 2. Stop inflating a few times and check it. 3. My hunch is you will have to squiggle the tire around on the rim to get it perfectly seated. # Those are stuff tires and do not easily form to the rim.
data.author: Dale Cannon

data.text: thanks‚Ä¶don‚Äôt think it was me saying not hard to install. They are a pain, but pretty bombproof once on.
data.author: Jon France

data.text: PAIN THAT IS. On the PAIN to get on tires I alwaysclean/scrub the inner rim area with a thin silicon spray. I mean Green scrubby hard so its slicker than wd40 on snot. Now your tire will seat evenly around the rim withour sticking.
data.author: Dale Cannon

data.text: Jon are you using rubber rim strips? I have had both the premium brand and the cheap rubber strips move around on the rim then keep the tire from seating in that area.. The good rim stirpes are extremely tight.
data.author: Dale Cannon

data.text: I will check that out, cheers
data.author: Jon France
